Okay, I need to summarize this document about Simon Johnson in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The document starts with his basic information: he's a British-American economist, current professor at MIT, former IMF Chief Economist, and co-winner of the 2024 Nobel Prize. His education includes Oxford and MIT. His career has involved teaching at Duke, MIT, and roles at the IMF and Peterson Institute. He's involved in various research groups and has written several books.

Key points to highlight: his academic positions, his role in the IMF, the Nobel Prize, his research areas, and his books. The main topic seems to be his career and contributions to economics, especially his work on technology and its societal impacts, as seen in "Power and Progress."

I should mention his Nobel Prize, his academic roles, his work on technology and inequality, and his co-authored books. Also, note the critical view of AI in his latest book. Need to keep it concise, 3-5 sentences. Avoid minor details like specific dates unless they're crucial. Make sure to include the main themes: economic research, technology's impact, and policy proposals.
</think>

Simon Johnson is a renowned British-American economist and MIT professor, known for his work on global economic systems, financial regulation, and the societal impacts of technology. He served as the IMF's Chief Economist (2007–2008) and co-authored the 2024 Nobel Prize-winning research on national prosperity, emphasizing institutional and technological factors. His books, such as *Power and Progress* (2023), critique AI's negative effects on jobs and democracy, advocating for policies to ensure technology benefits broader society. Johnson also focuses on economic inequality, financial stability, and innovation, contributing to debates on systemic risk and public policy. His career spans academia, think tanks, and advisory roles, shaping discourse on economic growth and technological governance.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Simon Johnson (economist)


# Simon Johnson (economist)



**Simon H. [S2] Johnson** (born January 16, 1963) is a British-American economist who has served as the Ronald A. [S3] Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the MIT Sloan School of Management since 2004. [S4] He also served as a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics from 2008 to 2019. [S5] Before moving to MIT, he taught at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business from 1991 to 1997. [S6] From March 2007 through the end of August 2008, he served as Chief Economist of the International Monetary Fund. [S7] In 2024, Johnson, Daron Acemoglu, and James A. [S8] Robinson were awarded the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for their comparative studies in prosperity between nations. [S9] ## Education

Born in 1963 in Sheffield, Johnson attended Abbotsholme School in Rocester and then went onto read PPE at Corpus Christi College, Oxford, graduating in 1984. [S10] He then received an MA in economics (with distinction) from the University of Manchester in 1986. [S11] He went on to doctoral study at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he was advised by Rudiger Dornbusch and received a PhD in economics in 1989, writing a dissertation entitled *Inflation, intermediation, and economic activity*. [S12] ## Career

From 1989 to 1991, Johnson was a junior scholar at Harvard University, where he was a member of the Harvard Academy for International and Area Studies and a fellow of its Russian Research Center. [S13] From 1991 to 1997, he taught at the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University, where he was an assistant professor till 1995, and an associate professor till 1997; he also directed its Center for Manager Development in St Petersburg, Russia from 1993 to 1995. [S14] He joined the faculty of MIT in 1997, and was tenured in 2002. [S15] At MIT, he is a research affiliate at Blueprint Labs, co-directs MIT’s Shaping the Future of Work Initiative, and heads its Global Economics and Management Group. [S16] Johnson has been a research associate at the NBER since 2004, and is an affiliate of BREAD. [S17] He is a fellow of the CEPR, and has sat on the board of directors of Fannie Mae since 2021. [S18] He co-founded the CFA Institute’s Systemic Risk Council, and has been a monthly columnist at Project Syndicate since 2010. [S19] In November 2020, Johnson was named a volunteer member of the Joe Biden presidential transition Agency Review Team to support transition efforts related to the United States Department of Treasury and the Federal Reserve. [S20] ## Affiliations

Johnson is a member of the International Advisory Council at the Center for Social and Economic Research (CASE). [S21] He is also a member of the Congressional Budget Office's Panel of Economic Advisers. [S22] From 2006 to 2007, he was a visiting fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, where he was a senior fellow from 2008 to 2019. [S23] He is on the editorial board of four academic economics journals. [S24] He has contributed to *Project Syndicate* since 2007. [S25] ## Research and publications

Simon Johnson is the author of relevant papers such as "Learning from Ricardo and Thompson: Machinery and Labor in the Early Industrial Revolution, and in the Age of AI" or "A Theory of Price Caps on Non-Renewable Resources". [S26] He wrote the 2010 book *13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown* (ISBN 978-0307379054), along with James Kwak, with whom he has also co-founded and regularly contributes to the economics blog The Baseline Scenario. [S27] He is also author of *White House Burning: Our National Debt and Why It Matters to You* (2013); *Jump-Starting America: How Breakthrough Science Can Revive Economic Growth and the American Dream* (2019), with Jonathan Gruber; and *Power and Progress: Our Thousand-Year Struggle Over Technology and Prosperity* (2023), with Daron Acemoglu. [S28] ### *Power and Progress*

Published in 2023, *Power and Progress* is a book on the historical development of technology and the social and political consequences of technology. [S4] The book addresses three questions, on the relationship between new machines and production techniques and wages, on the way in which technology could be harnessed for social goods, and on the reason for the enthusiasm around artificial intelligence (AI). [S1] He wrote the 2010 book *13 Bankers: The Wall Street Takeover and the Next Financial Meltdown* (ISBN 978-0307379054), along with James Kwak, with whom he has also co-founded and regularly contributes to the economics blog The Baseline Scenario. [S2] He is also author of *White House Burning: Our National Debt and Why It Matters to You* (2013); *Jump-Starting America: How Breakthrough Science Can Revive Economic Growth and the American Dream* (2019), with Jonathan Gruber; and *Power and Progress: Our Thousand-Year Struggle Over Technology and Prosperity* (2023), with Daron Acemoglu. [S3] ### *Power and Progress*

Published in 2023, *Power and Progress* is a book on the historical development of technology and the social and political consequences of technology. [S4] The book addresses three questions, on the relationship between new machines and production techniques and wages, on the way in which technology could be harnessed for social goods, and on the reason for the enthusiasm around artificial intelligence (AI). [S5] *Power and Progress* argues that technologies do not automatically yield social goods, their benefits going to a narrow elite. [S6] It offers a rather critical view of artificial intelligence, stressing its largely negative impact on jobs and wages and on democracy. [S7] Acemoglu and Johnson also provide a vision about how new technologies could be harnessed for social good. [S8] They see the Progressive Era as offering a model. [S9] And they discuss a list of policy proposals for the redirection of technology that includes market incentives, the break up of big tech, tax reform, investing in workers, privacy protection and data ownership, and a digital advertising tax.
